Fields.DialogueText: So this is Dublin...? It's rather gloomy. For some reason I was expecting something more...

Fields.MenuText: Well, it is that time of year.
Maybe the sky's just still in mourning for W.B. Yeats.
Minneapolis would look gloomy this kind of year, too, wouldn't it?

Fields.DialogueText: True, but I wasn't expecting to see something this dark and misty. Do you think it has to do with the Morganas?
Well, that's unexpectedly poetic of you!
How *dare* you! I'll have you know the rainy seasons within the City of Lakes are to die for! Especially when you sit down with a cup of coffee in the cold air!
Haha! Well, I suppose it's time to get to work, isn't it?
I concur. Let's unload the supplies and be about it. After all, I love serving up some home cooking! ... Do you think they'll like my shepherd's pie, Captain?
I'm not the person to ask on that front. Still, I think they'd love it regardless if you're native or not. Your cooking is absolutely out of this world.
Why... thank you, Captain! Hm, there are a lot of crates around this port. Was someone here already?
Perhaps the English decided to help them already? Beats me.
I guess our unloading job will be a bit of a hassle. You're up to the task, aren't you, Captain?
Well, if the English can't be bothered, I might as well do it. Come on, Minneapolis!
*ABOUT 2 HOURS LATER*
That should do it...! Oh, hey! The sun's coming through the mist!
Good gracious... this place is beautiful! I... How were they hiding all of this through mist!? Captain, please, where are the photographers!? I cannot wait to make a carving out of this!
Well, I'd hold off on that. Unless you feel like carving a Morgana into the wood, also?
Bless my bells... I guess that even in Ireland these little miscreants don't know proper manners. Uff da... are you ready, Captain? How about we show them how we do it back home?
Goodbye long sailing. Hello Ireland, hello Morganas. Engage!
@BATTLE
Ah, so this must be Bray? I didn't think it'd be - oh, wow! Captain, look at all of those people moving about! You almost wouldn't think it was wartime with the way they're strutting!
While it is unprofessional, I desire to one day have that level of fun on the job. And I agree. It's rather lively around here compared to Dublin. I wonder what's going on?
It could be some sort of special day. Or maybe they're all rushing to the other side of the dock? We did just unload... Hmhm! I'm proud of that one. Some nice white chili will warm them right up!
White chili... That's Eliezer's recipe, isn't it? He might throw a fuss if we don't save any for him.
I made sure to save him a pot before we packed the supplies, Captain. Don't worry. Hm... I don't see anyone going near the crates yet. Is something the matter?

Fields.MenuText: Maybe they aren't hungry?
Maybe White Chili isn't their thing?
Well, it isn't lunch yet, so...

Fields.DialogueText: That's a good joke, Captain. Don't you remember what we were sent here for? ... Maybe I did put a little too much spice in that porchetta?
How can they like it if they haven't even tried it!? Who in their right mind would say that about a dish that they've never indulged in? That's downright sour...
Dear me, I didn't even look at the clock! ...Though, would it hurt them to try at least a bite? I-I wouldn't mind it if they did! I just want to know how it tastes to them... y'know?
On second observation, it looks like not only everyone's going places, but a bunch of people are just sitting around and talking...
Hmmm... Wow, they really are! They must be incredibly brave to do that with Morganas and the war going on. Or do you think they don't care?
Actually... I think it's neither.
You don't? Well, what are they all doing out here when an attack could happen at any moment?
Minneapolis, what's the first thing you do in the morning?
Well, I get up, make breakfast for you and me, and then I go talk with you for a bit before we start the day!
You see what I'm getting at here? These people may care about the war, and some of them might know about the Morganas.
To have such emphasis on friends and family...! I'd love to see more of that in the States. A-And... maybe of myself.
How about some practice then? Those Morganas look like they're eyeing up the cargo.
Oh... They're in for it, now! Let's go together, Captain!
@BATTLE
Look at that boy with the overalls - he's dancing!
But that's not going to stop them from living their lives or seeing their friends and families.
... Captain, I'm honestly at a lost for words. This place is...
Majestic, isn't it? I remember coming here during training. Nice place to walk about and be relaxed, no?
It's too bad we can only go this far on the trail... These limitations I have for the ship are just so inconvenient. Uff da, what I wouldn't give to climb up there and take a few pictures.

Fields.MenuText: I can go up and take them for you if you want.
Who's to say we can't just bring the ship closer?
Have you considered doing sight carving, Minneapolis?

Fields.DialogueText: Captain! I'd love for you to do that, but I know you have duties to perform. I couldn't possibly ask that of you.
I suppose we can do that. But wouldn't that make the locals upset? I doubt anyone would want to see somebody like me when they're trying to look at the ocean.
Now, I would do that. However, the last time I did something like that, I ended up wasting an entire day while docked. ... For sure, the brass weren't happy for me for that one.
I think the best option here is to just go take some pictures. I wouldn't mind doing it.
Well, if it wouldn't inconvenience you, Captain.
Nothing inconveniences me at all, except for Morganas. ... And maybe the smell of Feng's incense, but mostly Morganas.
That's unfortunately one of my biggest worries, Captain.
What is? Morganas? They should be worried about *you.*
Hahaha! They should. I really do give them a hard time, thank you, Captain. It's just... I worry that I annoy people, or give the wrong impression to others. I-I don't mean to, but...
I know you don't mean to do it, Minneapolis. Like I said before, it's all about practice.
I understand that, Captain, but I feel like I have a duty as a ship to be a good role model for the sailors! It's not right to be... you know...
Minneapolis, it's all right. You're allowed to not know things and make mistakes. Being a good role model is also about being fallible.
Captain... You sound like you've done this before! Are you sure it's ok? That first meeting is really important, and I...
Marcus, Feng, and Eliezer gave you more chances. Trust me, Minneapolis. As long as you're better than you were yesterday, I think that's what makes a good role model.
Captain... Hmph! All right, I'll keep at it. Thank you so much. Um... So, where should we take pictures?
Well, there's a Morgana in our shot...
Maybe a destroyed Morgana would make a nice picture in contrast with the coastline... Hmhm! I like where this is going.
@BATTLE
Well, this is certainly a welcome wagon! All hands! All hands!
Come on, all of you! I'm about to show you how we do it! U! S! A! U! S! A!
I agree with Marcus - let's be about it! Besides, I have a booyah party to throw!
Minneapolis... Are you going to be making that chicken pot pie again? I really loved that.
Win this battle and I'll make you some extra portions, Marcus...
Aw, hell yeah! Let's go!
@BATTLE
Morganas eliminated. Well done, Minneapolis and Marcus!
Hell, yeah! ... Aw, dammit. I just remembered. I need to get below deck. I'm gonna be damned if I let Joe get dibs on the cola again! See you, Captain, Minneapolis!
See you later, Marcus! ... Oh! Don't you boys go eating all of the - drat. He's gone... Hmph! Well, that settles that.
If you need more supplies, I can go send for them. Command would probably be more than happy to send some our way thanks to how well the mission's going.
Actually, Captain. That reminds me... Did you see the people of Dublin in battle? I was... flabbergasted!

Fields.MenuText: There were so many barrages you'd think it's July.
I don't think I've seen that much raw firepower, ever.
The Fighting Irish indeed.

Fields.DialogueText: Sometimes I wonder if they stick fireworks into their cannons... What's got them so riled up for this? It's war, I understand that, but...
And I thought they were running low on supplies! I guess that's not entirely true, now is it? Well, maybe food supplies... Er, never mind. It's amazing just how hard they go at battle, y'know?
Captain, that's a football team, you silly! Hmm, though I suppose the name does hold true here. I wonder why they're fighting so hard?
Well, they gained their independence from Britain not twenty years ago, didn't they? I'd imagine they want to prove they can keep it.
So just recently they did? Hm... If they're aiming to keep it, they're certainly making a strong case. It's sort of... inspiring in a way.
Just like they want to keep freedom for their country, it's our job to make sure the world's free from Morganas.
Then... I want to be in the world! I'll keep fighting with you as long as it takes, Captain!
I'm on the same page. I'm glad to have you, Minneapolis.
Same to you, Captain. ... Oh, dearest me. I've been meaning to ask you: do you think Bolognese would be good for this party?
I wouldn't say no!
BOOYAH!!! PARTY!!! BOOYAH!!! BOOYAH!!! BOOYAH!!!
As ever! Looks like we've got another winner on our hands, Minneapolis.
I'm so glad that some of the Irish forces decided to join us tonight. I was looking for a chance to show off my cooking, you know? I want to be fully fledged in Irish cuisine before I'm done here!
Well, that's an ambitious project if I've ever heard one.
Ambition is just another word for perseverance, Captain. And you know how I am about that, don't you know?
Evening to you both. Nice to meet you, Captain, Minneapolis. I humbly thank you for allowing our regiment to attend such a marvelous event.
Ah, you must be McGrane. Hello! It's nice to meet an actual Irishman for the first time. ... Tell me, do you all actually eat haggis? Or is that just a rumor? I've heard it's rather bitter.
I beg your pardon?
Well, if you don't eat haggis, I guess you're fond of your alcohol, aren't you? I've heard you have entire nights for it! It's a real party-starter.

Fields.MenuText: So, McGrane, how are you enjoying the party?
Did you hear about Dublin?
[Nudge Minneapolis]

Fields.DialogueText: You took the words right out of my mouth, Captain. How's the party, McGrane?
Oh, it was so beautiful! You all did such a wonderful job fighting, and I'm so excited to have you all here. Do you like it so far?
O-Oh! Captain... A-Ahem! Sorry, McGrane, what I'm meaning to ask is: do you like the party? I did my best to keep consistent with the food, too. How is that?
I'm glad to be here! I must really thank you both for inviting us aboard. It's quite lovely here, the people are brilliant, the atmosphere's fantastic...
Oh, McGrane, I'm so glad you're liking this party. I was worried that I might get off on the wrong foot with all of you!
We can share recipes! ... But I think we'll have to share salvos in a minute. I see some Morganas off of port.
Those...! How dare they interrupt again!? It's time for some manners...
Some rowdy boys these are, yeah? Captain, let's rough them up, shall we?
With pleasure. Let's go, you two!
@BATTLE
Just don't include me in brawls. I don't know my own strength!
And the food! Jaysus! How do you do your shepherd's pie? I must know!
And I'd love to share my recipe with you. Would that be acceptable to share, Captain?
*sigh*
Now that that's over, I had a couple questions for you, McGrane!
Really? Well, I'm in a good mood. Long as nothing's out there, I'd be pleased to answer. Ask away!
Well, I have to ask about something I saw earlier. When the Captain and I arrived, you were all out and about like it was nothing but a Millers game back home!
Well, if you must ask... You're familiar with the concept of the "stiff upper lip?"
No... What is it?
Good answer. You're better off not knowing.
How can you say that when there are Morganas everywhere? When international commerce is barely moving, and you're surrounded by enemies!?
I can say it and I can say it loud. What matters is that even through the hardest times, we're willing to smile and brave it through.
Hmm! I'll remember that. Second question... Alcohol's a big part of your culture, right?
I can see how a Yank might think so...
We Minnesotans love our pints much, too! I just...
Hahaha! I think I get it. Make no mistake, Minneapolis! Just because we get together in pubs to socialize doesn't mean we're all drunkards! The same would go for you Americans, wouldn't it?
I don't think everyone loves alcohol back in the States, now that you mention it.

Fields.MenuText: Prohibition was kind of a big thing.
What's next? Kids are going to start drinking?
I'm more of a soda guy, myself.

Fields.DialogueText: Hard to believe that ended so recently, isn't it?
I will admit, it's not a good look. You should enjoy that when you're a grown-up!
I *knew* it! No wonder you wouldn't try any of Feng's Bright Dragon Cocktail! Poor fella looked crushed...
Anyway, alcohol doesn't make a person. Neither does anything else. I think a person makes oneself, personally.
I'd say I'd drink to that, but the young lady might take it amiss.
Captain... I... Thank you for saying that. I--
*ALARM*
...I'm going to to lose my temper. Captain, please come with me. ... *Now.*
Jaysus... What's this pressure I feel?
You get used to it.
@BATTLE
How do you do that when you're in war - let alone surrounded by Morganas?
Nobody knows that better than the Irish.
Sure, we've just lived through worse than this. We've had centuries of learning how to get on with our lives while the bastards try to starve us out.
Good morning, Captain!
Minneapolis! You're in high spirits today. What's got you all ramped up?
Well, there happened to be a bake-off in Dublin yesterday. I submitted a dish on behalf of us here to see where I could improve my cooking. I love feedback.
And how it go? ... Wait, is that a blue ribbon you're holding? W-what did you even submit!?
I made my shepherd's pie - my award-winning shepherd's pie, now! But that's not all: look at these letters!

Fields.MenuText: Holy hell, there's so many!
Wait, Douglas Hyde... Minneapolis, is this the president of Ireland!?
I can't believe it. Minneapolis, you've done wonderfully!

Fields.DialogueText: Captain! Don't say such sacrilege so sparingly! You'll catch the devil's fork if you go like that... But yes! There's quite a lot.
Land alive, you should've seen me when I got that! I was so shocked that I almost fell out of my chair... I can't believe he was in attendance!
Captain! Thank you so much. I did it out of love, you know? The pie came out beautifully, but I never thought I'd win first prize!
These letters are all saying how much they enjoyed it... I'm proud of you for sharing, Minneapolis.
Think nothing of it, Captain. After all, we came here to help relieve the Irish of their food problems--so it seemed only fair.
Minneapolis, what do you think the Irish liked about your food?
I think it's because I used local ingredients and made sure to keep it as closely associated with Irish cuisine as possible. McGrane lent me a few cookbooks as well!
I think that right there is what made it so successful, Minneapolis. Don't you see? Instead of assuming things, you went right to the source and found out for yourself.
And it most certainly paid off! ... Ah, Captain, I think I'm better seeing your point now. Though... I will admit, I'm still a bit concerned with how I act at gatherings sometimes.
I understand. Don't worry, it's a work in progress, much like this war and... Well, it looks like we have more work to do.
Perhaps this Morgana would be willing to help me figure out some new recipes? Hmhm... Let's find out!
@BATTLE
This is horrid... I knew some parts of Dublin weren't as well off, but...
Such is the way of the war. Captain, do we have those rations handy?
Right here. This should do it. For now, anyway - one load of deliveries isn't going to solve the underlying problems.
I've heard that some cities in the United States are very much the same. Though I'm one to talk. I could tell you stories about my neighborhood, everyone practically on top of each other...
Not all cities within the United States are like this, Feng. I know some great cities that keep their people up off the ground.
I've heard the Midwest is especially bad. No offense, Minneapolis, but I've heard your namesake is one of the worst contenders.
... How dare you!? Minneapolis is a great city!
Explain that to the poor, the blacks - hell, even the natives have a rough go there. I know big cities, Minneapolis. Your namesake has problems to anyone who isn't rich.
That's not--! Our city provides everyone the opportunities to get more out of life!
Why is it then that people are still starving out there? Does President Roosevelt not see that? Or are your senators too busy?
Enough, both of you. We didn't come here to bicker about cities. We came here to help the people of Dublin.
But, Captain! Minneapolis isn't like that! You know that's not true...

Fields.MenuText: You're wonderful, Minneapolis. But everywhere could use some work.
Just because your namesake may not be the best, that doesn't mean you aren't.
The Depression changed everything. Now we have to pick up the slack.

Fields.DialogueText: C-Captain... I understand that, but... Minneapolis isn't all that bad... You're right, though.
Captain... Thank you... I'm sorry.
Captain... We should be helping the people out here! I agree. I apologize.
My apologies to you both. I stepped out of line.
It's all right, Feng. I admit. There's some stuff we could work on at home. For now though, let's help Dublin.
Ah! Incoming enemies! Maybe the Morganas were feeding off of the negative energy?
Feeding time's over, then. Captain?
Right away. Prepare for battle.
@BATTLE
There's poverty everywhere, but the Morganas are exacerbating the problem here. International trade is getting pretty damn hard if you live on an island.
Captain, I've been thinking.
What have you been thinking about, Minneapolis? Was it that altercation with Feng yesterday?
No, not at all! In fact, I spoke with Feng afterwards, and it turns out we're very particular about some aspects of our countries. A-anyway, I've been thinking about not hosting a booyah this week.
What!? Well, why wouldn't you hold it?
I want to instead prepare a feast for the people of Dublin. They've been such gracious hosts. And I want to help the cold and homeless, like Bunyan and Babe would.

Fields.MenuText: I'll get the crew on board as well, or at least try to.
Minneapolis... I... I don't know what to say.
I'll stay right by you.

Fields.DialogueText: If they don't, you can just leave them to me, Captain. Those boys can be rowdy, but what's to do but convince them?
Like you said, Captain. People and Belles alike should be able to make themselves in this world. And what I want to make myself is useful.
Then hand me a ladle, Captain! I'll get you an apron! Dublin will eat well these days!
This is a really big step up, but I think Command can handle the demand.
We're already meeting the demand several times over with weapons. Why can't we with food? Regardless, I say we should begin soon.
How about some more Irish cuisine? I hear they make great soups.
Actually, I want to try this old English recipe I've seen floating around some cookbooks. They call it "dillegrout."
Ah, that dish they served kings way back when? That sounds like fun.
It'll be more fun to make with you, Captain. I've seen you cooking before, and I'd love to give you some pointers.
Maybe you could give me some pointers on battle, too?
What do you mean by-- Oh. Hmhmhm. These children could REALLY use some guidance when it comes to not messing with me.
And how. Let's crack some skulls.
@BATTLE
Haha! The operation was a complete success! Thank you so much, Captain, you've done so well...
As have you, Minneapolis. It's hard to believe that setting up a food shelf like that could be that simple! Damn, I wish we had more of that back in the States.
Maybe one day... Hm? McGrane! Is that you? What brings you here? ... What is that you're holding?
Good afternoon, Minneapolis, Captain. I've brought something for you both that you may like. Consider it a gift from the people of Dublin.

Fields.MenuText: ... A sword made of obsidian?
It's a statue!
... McGrane, are you sure this is okay?

Fields.DialogueText: Pahahahaha! No, no, Captain. This isn't a sword. Please, I present you the Freedom of Dublin! You and Minneapolis, both helped us out far more than ever anticipated... Please, accept our gratitude.
Not just any statue, Captain! I hereby on behalf of the city of Dublin present you and Minneapolis with our key. For your humanitarian efforts and willingness to go above and beyond!
Captain, I have no trouble presenting the Freedom of Dublin to you. Please, both you and Minneapolis have made this young soldier proud of his fellow man.
McGrane...
... I'm at a loss for words! McGrane... Thank you, thank you, thank you!!!
Please, please. You both have done amazingly here in Dublin. Continue your efforts. I cannot stress enough how much you've relieved her of her woes.
Joe!
*pant* *pant* C-Captain! Big Sister! We've got two ounces of trouble!
What's going on?
The RAF has sent us a message! We need to get over to Belfast immediately! They're under attack by Morganas - it's under siege! We need to leave *now!*
Damn it! Minneapolis, prepare to leave port!
C-Captain, there are Morganas blocking us!
... Taking advantage of our kind nature. For them to go this low...
B-Big Sis?
UNFORGIVABLE. *STOMP STOMP STOMP*
Captain, you'd best follow her. She's going to wreck house!
I'm already on it. McGrane, Joe -with me. We've got to go save Belfast!
@BATTLE
... Hm? Who's that?
Yeah. The Morganas did a lot of damage. Ireland may not have been hit this hard in a single day since Cromwell - and Belfast may *never* have been hit this hard.
I *refuse* to stand by and let this happen any longer. Captain. Please give me orders.
Wreck house.
Yeah. You. Betcha.
@BATTLE
No Morganas on radar anymore. Well done, Minneapolis.
Captain... Look at this place. The Morganas may be gone, but... These people! This doesn't look anything like Dublin...
Yeah. The Morganas may have been probing the Liffey shipyards, but I think they were genuinely out to wreck Harland and Wolff. The people here look shellshocked - maybe literally.

Fields.MenuText: In a way, I'm almost glad they hit Dublin first. If the Morganas wanted to build tension between the north and south, sparing one side would be a way to start.
When it rains, it pours.
Belfast - the Belle - is going to be going totally berserk right now.

Fields.DialogueText: I can imagine. If the people of Minneapolis were hurt like the people here, I don't know what I'd do...
Raining is an understatement. It looks like a damn typhoon went through this place. The people look so tired, Captain. What do we do?
... We have to do something! Captain, please, we have to!
Let's make them a feast, Minneapolis - along with all the medical care we can provide. We still have some supplies left over.
I agree. What these people could use are some nice cups of wild rice and maybe some porchetta? I wonder, will they like my shepherd's pie?
Only one way to find out. I'll grab my apron.
Haha! I'll get the ovens and grills ready. Let's get into it, Captain!
Ah, glad to see everyone's smiling now.
It makes you feel warm, doesn't it?
Hey, Captain. Do you see those people over there?
What is... Ah!? Those people! They're beating on those men!
We have to do something, Captain!

Fields.MenuText: Hey! You! Stop!
Stop in the name of the League of Nations!
You either quit that right now, or it's Minnesota hospitality for you jokers!

Fields.DialogueText: Stop it! Quit beating on him! Hey!
What you're doing is a crime! Stop this at once!
That's not a threat. That's a PROMISE!
Damn! They ran off...
They're... still breathing, Captain. I'll get them to the infirmary immediately. Why..? Who did this?
See those signs on the ground?
But that... Why does that mean these people get beaten up? Why would anyone do this?
Sadly, it's not that much unlike what's going on back home. It's just like Feng said.
... Captain, I want to go after them. I want to make them answer. Grr, I'll give those boys more than just a stern talking to!
Not our jurisdiction. The only thing we can do is report it.
... I won't stand for this. Captain, please. Send a report to the British authorities as soon as possible.
I will. Let's take these folks to the infirmary and get them patched up.
Hmph... Should've figured the Morganas would show up at this point. I can sense them. Captain, could you please?
Yes, ma'am.
@BATTLE
Apparently there's been some talk over the last day or so of implementing conscription in Northern Ireland after all. I think our victims were probably protesters.
And, if I understand the politics correctly, they'd probably also be just as happy to see this place governed by Dublin rather than the current powers that be.
... Which might explain why I think I saw a uniform or two in that mob.
Captain, are those folks we rescued yesterday all right? And have you heard word from the RAF?
They're fine, just a bit bruised and scraped. I called the RAF, but I got no response.
How can they just sit there and pretend like nothing's happening!? Their own people are getting beaten in the streets, and others are going hungry?
It's right out of the Morgana playbook - at least when they're at their most effective. Cut off supplies, stoke political divisions, turn people against one another. This is fertile ground for it.
But... we have to do something, Captain. I don't want to sit by and let the violence keep building.
We can help cool things down by giving the people food and allowing them to clean themselves up on the ship.
Okay, then. I'll set up some liaisons near port and we can send them discreetly. Once we have a program running, we can see about expanding its reach.
Thank you, Captain... Thank you so much. It just... It's not right.
Yeah. But at least some of it might be not right in ways we can't fix.
That doesn't mean we can't do anything. Let's go, Captain.
... Morganas. Again with this, really?
Captain, you know as much as I do that we can't simply wish them away.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
The fact that we've seen it in other places means the people in charge should know how to deal with it!
Instead it seems like they're just letting it happen.
Hm. The conscription argument is getting more heated, too. All the demagogues are coming out.

Fields.MenuText: But all that is politics. It's outside our remit.
I just wish I knew what to do about it.
I'm not sure our usual efforts to encourage volunteerism are helping, either.

Fields.DialogueText: And tacitly offering sanctuary onboard for people who need it. If we can manage the security issues...
I'll keep an eye on everybody. Promise.
Now Minneapolis and the Captain take a moment to reflect on their work.
About three more rounds and we're done. Good work, Minneapolis.
Hehe! Never doubt the intuition of a true frontierswoman. Nothing beats a good, hearty round of cooking! And soon, Belfast'll be fed.
That's great to hear. Honestly... I thought we made too much food, but now instead of the crew we're feeding the people.
It's a great feeling, isn't it, Captain? To be honest, your little talk last week gave me an idea.

Fields.MenuText: Was it the one about the potato wedges?
Ah, you mean taking pictures for the Pulitzer Prize.
So, you finally figured it out, huh?

Fields.DialogueText: I would love to implement them as part of a meal for one day, but no. What I had in mind was something much larger.
Wasn't Eliezer going to do that? Anyway, that's not my plan.
So you know what I'm talking about, then? I knew you would, Captain.
What is your plan, exactly?
My plan? Simple. Once this entire war is over, I've found I'd like to dedicate some of my time to the people who are less fortunate.
People need help first and foremost. There's plenty back home that aren't getting it.
Minneapolis... That's... I have to say, that knocks me off my feet. I would love to be a part of that, too, when this is all over.
Of course you can, Captain! After all, a true frontierswoman's work is never done.
I suppose it isn't. But now that this is all said and done, do you want to eat lunch and listen to the radio?
I would love to right now, but it appears some others have started chomping at my bit.
Let's feed 'em more then they can handle, then.
@BATTLE
I want to make sure they're fed, and in a home and a job. I want to teach them what you've taught me.
No, no siree. I'm not about that. I want to take care of them and see them strong. Everybody deserves a shot.
And so the Captain and Minneapolis collected food from around the fleet, and from friendly ports from Cork to Plymouth to Continental Europe.
Some was distributed through Belfast's churches, and some directly from Minneapolis herself. In the end, hundreds - maybe thousands - were helped.
As the normal flow of commerce resumed, and as the Captain made a few off-the-record phone calls detailing the success of voluntary naval enlistment policies, tempers seemed to cool.
Pardon. It seems to us that this is where the supplies are coming from. May I speak with the captain of this vessel?
Would you perchance be--
This is in fact the captain. And judging by those uniforms you must be the Royal Ulster Constabulary. I am the USS Minneapolis. What can we do you for?
Minneapolis, right... What brings us here to the docks of Belfast today is we've heard of an unregulated shipment of food coming in. It was supposed to be released by a Constabulary member.
Sorry - we didn't receive any such orders. It's been hectic getting the food prepared and dispersed.
Hectic, but effective. If you'll notice, a lot of people are smiling and are no longer hungry.
Flying in the face of regulations and then dispersing food without so much as a telegram isn't the way things are done, no matter how well-intentioned. That food wasn't dispersed correctly!
I fail to see how it wasn't. Everyone's all right now that they're in rations.

Fields.MenuText: Really, there isn't an issue here.
Part of the INPF mandate is to deliver emergency assistance to vulnerable civilian populations. It shouldn't be a surprise to your bosses.
We don't want any trouble. We came to feed Belfast.

Fields.DialogueText: I agree with the Captain. Any sort of issue you may have with us was not mentioned at port, nor was it ever mentioned by any local official.
Our orders were to provide emergency support to the people of Belfast. We never received any order to not do so, nor to wait for a governing body.
We really don't. If you could all please move along, both the Captain and I must continue our work.
Now, see here. This is not America - this is Northern Ireland. When you are here, you will abide by our rules. And if you won't, you will be held accountable. Please, act your age.

Ah, I see. Well, if I am to act my age, which... Hmm... 5, technically, but I'd say I'm about 22. Therefore, I'll ask you: how would you have dispersed the supplies? Would you have given them equally?
What sort of outlandish question is--
Or would you have given it to your coreligionists? Oh, that reminds me: you are Protestant, Constable? I myself am a... Christian Universalist. We both worship God and believe in Jesus, don't we?
Minneapolis, stop. Don't escalate.
I don't mean to escalate! It just... makes me a bit frustrated is all. You have all of these people who believe in God as you do and love Ireland. But... there's an issue.
Are you accusing us of withholding rations from citizens of the British Empire?
I'm not accusing you of anything. I *am* acting how many of your more senior civil servants are Catholic. Just for a sense of how easily you could distribute the food in the poorer parts of town.
Come back when you want to act like real men! Hmph. Blowhards.
... I honestly don't know whether to formally caution you or hug you.
Look alive, Captain! We've got Morganas now. Must've been attracted to the pure sludge that was spilling out of their mouths and ears.
@BATTLE
Morale is necessary during these times, sir. So, if I may be impertinent and ask: what's the issue?

Fields.MenuText: I think she's saying there might be room for improvement in the system.
Tread lightly, Minneapolis.
Kinda sounds like it, huh?

Fields.DialogueText: ... I couldn't tell you, Miss.
I understand. If there are no further questions, you may all take your leave. Unless you wanted to help with the cleaning?
An issue that I'm worried might have left people going hungry.
Well, what we're been hearing is that you've been going out of your way to supply our seditious elements...
What, the protestors?
We feed the people who come to us in need. That's all.
That's it, everyone! Put your back into it! That's how we do it back home, so bring some of America here to Ireland!
Everyone dances about in a gigantic circle amidst a giant makeshift light tree made out of a drying pole on deck. This, with food, games, and a good drink is the essence of BOOYAH.
I really think this is what we needed after that whole event in Belfast the other day. You really did carry yourself well, Minneapolis.
Oh, don't think a thing of it, Captain. You know me by now. I'm not going to take something like that sitting down. Mmm, this kombucha you've made is wonderful.
I had some help from an unlikely source.
Damn RIGHT you did, Captain! WOOOOOOO! This party is awesome!
And here I thought you didn't like to be plastered, Eliezer!
Screw that noise! I love having a party, is what I love. Seriously, Captain, Minneapolis, you're the best! Oh, hey... That Irish lady's eyeing me... I'm gonna go dance!
Be safe, Eliezer! I swear, I hope that boy doesn't get in too much trouble.

Fields.MenuText: Didn't Marcus do the same thing the other party?
He'll probably be ok.
Maybe he still didn't learn after your talk, huh?

Fields.DialogueText: He at least sat out and sobered up a bit before going headfirst.
I wonder sometimes about that boy.
That's the beauty of learning, Captain. Sometimes you have to make mistakes to succeed. Sometimes mistake after mistake.
Sometimes you have to really question yourself on it. Well, it looks the Irish crew is having fun.
They sure are! I made certain this time that there was plenty of stout, local dishes, and some customary Irish music. They sure know how to bring a house down, don't they?
I'll say--
*CRASH*
That was the side of the ship! We need to-- Minneapolis?
I will make a rug out of their little ghostly hairs. Sometimes, I wonder if I had more cannons, would it be cool, or would it be cruel? Hm, time to find out.
... Minneapolis?
@BATTLE
Why. Are. There. So. Many. Of. Them. At. My. Party?

Fields.MenuText: A terrifying, rhetorical question.
Do I look like I know the answer to that?
Minneapolis! Please, you're going to wreck us!

Fields.DialogueText: It's not rhetorical, it's a legitimate question: why are they so insistent on ruining everything!?
Please, for all that is holy: give me one. I am growing so tired of having my parties interrupted by them.
I. Will. Not. This has been the third time this trip this has happened. I refuse to let it happen again. I don't want the party to be ruined!
Minneapolis, there won't be a party if you're rampaging like this!
Minneapolis, the Captain's right. You need to calm down.
McGrane!? A-Are you and your crew enjoying the party?
We are - it was worth the trip north all on its own! But you need to relax too, Minneapolis. Please, let us take over from here.
B-But--
Just fire away the cannons, Minneapolis. McGrane's right. You deserve to have fun, too!
HAVE AT THEM, LADS!!!
*RAUCOUS CHEERING*
We've got this.
Captain...
Let's go!
@BATTLE
Captain, I've been hearing my cannons, but have been mostly partying. Are you all alright?

Fields.MenuText: I told you, we've got this.
I could use a bit of a workout anyhow.
A real captain allows close companions to rest when they need it.

Fields.DialogueText: If you say so, Captain... I'm just... I'm still so cross despite finally being able to party.
This hardly counts as a workout! You'll tire yourself out at that rate! How is all this mess any fun?
Captain... But... I'm a Belle, I should be giving it my all. I can't just ignore everything... It makes me angry.
Tell me, Minneapolis. You ever hear of brawling? Just some friendly sparring between lads, nothing major.
I'm not familiar with it. You mean to tell me that you fight for fun!?
Yes, ma'am! Practicing your abilities, having some laughs, and then grabbing a good pint afterwards. That's the essence! That's the spirit of brawling! Cu Chulainn himself took part in it regularly!
I understood that reference. But McGrane is right, Minneapolis. You can have as much fun in battle as at a party. It's all in how you see it!
But, Captain... I'm a ship. I just can't fight with other people!
Maybe you could ask the other Belles? I know there's a few always up for a spar.
Hmm... I think... Why, that's a wonderful idea! Not to mention, I could pick up recipes, cultures, and the like along the way! Hohoh, I'm excited, Captain...
Turn that excitement into partying! Because the night is still young, right, everybody!?
YEAH! BOOYAH! BOOYAH! BOOYAH!
I never pegged you for a vivacious one, Captain. You and Minneapolis... Why, you both might as well be Irish at this point. Shall we have a go with these Morganas?
Absolutely! Let's push these good times on!
@BATTLE
Haha! All right, this is actually quite fun! Come on, Morganas - if you want to party so much, I'll give you some!
That's the spirit! Let's go!
@BATTLE
And don't come back... Hah... They're kind of thinning.
It looks like it. There are still some more, but it looks like we've got some more time to ourselves now.
Who made this dillegrout!? I must know!

Fields.MenuText: Why don't you ask the lady herself?
It's obvious, isn't it?
[Smirk at Minneapolis]

Fields.DialogueText: I'm the cook. I take you like it? From that face... It seems so!
Captain, that's rude! But, yes, I am the maker of the dillegrout. It's actually a really fun and delicious dish, too. Would you like the recipe?
Yes, that's me! I will admit, charring the chicken required a bit of gumption on my part. Luckily, Marcus knew how to work it. Do you like it?
My goodness... like it!? I love it! The entire damn crew loves it! Please, ma'am. A recipe, a smidge of ingredients - hell, we'd beg you to make more!
Why... I'm flattered! I originally thought that I didn't do Irish cuisine justice, even after I won that blue ribbon. Dillegrout isn't Irish, mind you, but it's from the next island over!
I'm not in for specifics! And you thought *wrong.* Your cooking is by far the best we've ever had. It's incomparable to anything else!
MINNEAPOLIS! THANK YOU!
Lord... I think...
Minneapolis, are you alright?
Captain?
Yes?
I think I might cry...
Hmph! All right! The party's almost over for you Morganas. So... Er, what would this be? Captain?

Fields.MenuText: Curtains!
When the band starts packing up, I think.
The last call for alcohol.

Fields.DialogueText: Since when were you a thespian, Captain? Maybe another time I can show you my collection of things the Hennepin Theater sent me.
I will admit, I've never heard traditional Irish folk music before. However, I'm starting to see the appeal... It just makes you tap your feet.
Haha! That's it. That's it. All right, Morganas! The Captain and I have been gracious hosts. But the bouncers are moving in!
One last show for 'em, then! Let's rock!
Let's make it a good ending!
@BATTLE
And that's that. Hmm... I had no idea Morganas sank like that.
They do if you hit them hard enough. All right! Everyone! The booyah party's over. Thank you for attending!
*CHEERING*
Now before you all go... You all made this mess. Therefore, you're going to clean it up! ...Unless you'd like to - Oh. Oh, my.
After witnessing the flower child in battle, nobody felt like making her upset again. Therefore, all people of every creed, color, and cap took part in cleaning up.
Thank you all for coming! Please, come back again when the next one happens! Ah...
Ah! *Rustling*
Hahahaha! Nice catch, Captain. I'm sorry, I think I overdid it a bit there.
I think you've earned some rest... I've said it before, and I'll say it again, Minneapolis. You're amazing...
Thank you, Captain... Captain?
Yes, Minneapolis?
You want to go listen to the end of that soccer game?
'Course I do. Come on. Let's go.
So... Today's the day we head back to Dublin, eh?
Can you hear it calling your name?
Not especially, no. It's just... Wow! We've done so much here. The people are all looking so much better than they were before.

Fields.MenuText: Sometimes all you need is a party.
Good food opens up many doors.
Couldn't have done it without you, Minneapolis.

Fields.DialogueText: Indeed! People need to get out and get up some more. After all - work is important, but having fun should come second on that list, if not equally first.
It certainly opened up McGrane's door wide. I haven't seen somebody smile like that since I talked to one of my boys about the Millers' '35 pennant!
Captain! Cut that out! You're going to make me blush, and I shouldn't be. After all, you were in this as much as I was!
It feels like I've gotten to know Ireland a whole lot more. And I'm thankful for that - Hey, Minneapolis, what are you writing?
Oh, it's a letter to the Irish Senate. You see, there's this place really far in the southwest called Killarney.
Sounds majestic.
I'm asking them to preserve that park. The pictures I've seen, the people I've talked to about it... I wish I could visit it! But right now I'm content sending a letter.
Well, I hope that letter finds them well.
I'd like to visit it one day. ...Grgh, if only I weren't bound to this ship and this wretched seawater. I'd go everywhere! Especially in freshwater!
Maybe one day, huh? Is this it in the picture? ... Man, that's beautiful. I can see why you'd want to preserve it.
I'm glad you can see, Captain. Some of the others felt like I was wasting my time. "It's just a bunch of rocks and trees!" "They'll never keep it like we do!" Hagh... I wish... I wish they could see.
See what? Forgive me for asking such an obvious question.
No, Captain, it's fine. What I'm trying to say is... Technology is fine, but... This world, and how it is when you can just be within the natural moment... That right there is true beauty.
I vote we go on a nature expedition for next time, then. I... I want to see more of this natural state.
I'd love to take you along, Captain. Such trips are eye-opening and let you really feel everything... But it appears a brawl is brewing for now. Are you up for some practice?
As always.
@BATTLE
Some of the Irish crew told me about it. Real natural beauty. Emerald leaves, fudge rocks, crystalline water...
Captain! I'm back with some souvenirs from Dublin. You should've seen the look on their faces when they saw me walking about.
There you are! Well, what did you get?
Lots of things. Have a look!

Fields.MenuText: Good holly, this frame is huge! Is that... Cu Chulainn?
This is a luxurious quilt... And this art, look at these patterns!
These wood carvings... Did you make these?

Fields.DialogueText: Indeed it is! I overheard his legend from a couple of the Irish crew and I wanted something to remember it by. Look at the spear, the muscles... the beard! He's like an Irish Paul Bunyan, a real hero!
Look, you can see the Ulster Cycle embroidered on the front. And on the back... Ta-da! How about that? A bunch of brave soldiers fighting for what they believe in. That old woman knows how to weave!
Actually, no. There was a young man near the town square that was selling them. I talked with him for a bit and gave him some tips! That boy shows great promise. See how he captured Dublin?
This is quite the haul... Let me guess, is all of this going to go into the museum?

You bet it is! That's another thing I noticed.  We have a lot of art by a lot of good artists, but... I feel like we could use something local, don't you know what I'm saying? We should get everybody.
I agree on that. Maybe we can do some talking to the museum staff when we get back there, huh?
It'll certainly be a big talk. Uff da... I can just imagine the curator asking us what we're thinking about, and why we think this art should belong there.
Well, all art IS subjective.
Isn't that the truth! And I think everybody should be able to subvert expectations, somehow. Ah.... Maybe I'm wishful, Captain.
Well, then let's wish together. Heck, I wouldn't mind talking to the curator with you when we do.
Would you really?
Of course I would. Besides, you've made me start to really appreciate art.
I-I have!? Captain... I'm so glad that I—wait, what's that!?
It's an... erm... interactive art piece.
... It could use some red.
@BATTLE
I don't understand, Captain. It's been so quiet today...
Maybe everybody's going to church?
But it's not Sunday. That's not right... Hm, I wish I could've said goodbye at least...
Yeah, I wish I could've, too—
SURPRISE!!!!

Fields.MenuText: OH, WHAT THE--
Y-You guys!
Ah... Damn. Now this, this is an Irish goodbye!

Fields.DialogueText: What indeed!? What's all this!? I... Did you all throw a party for us!?
Oh my stars and garters... Oh... Oh please don't... Oh, I'm going to cry... This is...!
Good gracious... Is this all for us!? Y-You... Captain, am I dreaming? Please. Please don't wake me if I am!
We heard you heading out, Minneapolis. From one soldier to another, we'd all like to congratulate you for your hard work. Instead of you cooking, we elected to treat you all to a feast! Bring it out!
Oh my... Look at all of this stuff! The meat, beer, and pastries...! Y-You really shouldn't have!
McGrane... This is something else. You all didn't have to do this—yet you totally went above and beyond!
I'd say the same thing of you and Minneapolis, Captain. You've helped us brave dire times and given us more than we could have asked for. And for that... you get a proper introduction to Irish craic!
This is wonderful! I won't hold back, then... I'll show you how we party down! Come along, Captain!
Time to put on some good shoes. Let's get it moving!
I would like to start right now, but one of the lads said they've spotted Morganas coming on the radar... Would you mind?
Already on it.
Good things come to those who wait, after all. The Captain and I will have this done in no time.
Let's throw down!
@BATTLE
I'm still so happy about that party... Ah, the fact that they gave me these jersies is the icing on the cake...
Irish Rugby... Honestly, they're really beautiful.
I really should play more sports when I have time. It's quite fun, you know?

Fields.MenuText: Now, Minneapolis. You know I suck at charades.
Missing it already?
Minneapolis...

Fields.DialogueText: If you're bad at charades, what does that make me? Worse? ... Ahahahaha! No, no... Captain, I just... I miss everybody.
Like you wouldn't believe.
For the *last* time! Don't you Minneapolis me, Captain! I'm not a kid! ... But I do miss them.
I promise you'll see them again. I know that we can make time at some point to come back here, and when you do it'll be great.
That's not all, Captain.
It isn't? Then, what else is there? C'mon. You can tell me.
When I saw Belfast and heard Feng's words about Minneapolis... I know I said all of that stuff about helping out my namesake, but... I don't know where to start.
I... empathize with you on that. I am a captain, not a developmental planner. Fortunately, though, I happen to know some people who are.
... I saw them, Captain. They were hungry, down on their luck... forgotten at best. It's taken me a while to come to this conclusion, but... Damn it, I don't want to see my namesake as such.
It'll take a long time to make progress, I can assure you that.
I want to try. I want to do my best for them. I want to learn how to be a better Belle, and teach everyone how to work with one another.
I'll help you every step of the way, Minneapolis.
Captain... Thank you. Thank you for believing in me.
Thank you for believing in me, Minneapolis.
... There's a Morgana right next to—
Hahaha! I didn't want to kill the mood. All right, let's go.
@BATTLE
—and thus while traveling through Ireland did I learn something important! As a crew, we must strive to make sure everyone has an opportunity!
*GENERAL SOUNDS OF AGREEMENT*
The Captain and I have seen firsthand what it means to break barriers and establish new connections with people we don't know. Therefore, I'd say it's all time for you to get to know each other.
*GENERAL SOUNDS OF ACKNOWLEDGEMENT, SOME CONFUSION*
Now, now. This won't happen right away, mind you. But I expect that you all start treating each other with more respect! I want to see everyone embrace at least one other as a trusted companion!
*CONFUSION*

Fields.MenuText: Minneapolis is right, everyone. It's high time we learned.
Everything that you're holding in now needs to get out.
The more you like each other, the harder you can party.

Fields.DialogueText: And if not all the way learned, we need to get a head start. The Captain is right. Now, what do you all say to getting to know each other better?
The Irish taught me how to brawl, and I think I can give all of you a little advice on to how to healthily let that out. Not only by yourselves, but as a team! Are you with me!?
And when you work better together, it's like a party every day! And I know that better than anyone else: I work with the Captain. Who wants to get that party started, huh!?
*CHEERING AND GENERAL AGREEMENT*
Fantastic, Minneapolis. It looks like everybody's amped up to start working hard again.
I hope they are! It's going to get harder from here on out, and comrades will be paramount. ... I'm just glad I'm with you, Captain.
With you in a firefight? Pah, we can't lose. You remember that time in Belfast where you bunker busted that Morgana?
Oohoo! That was a lot of fun. I remember how things went flying everywher—
*ALARM*
Always interrupting me... Hmph! Come on, all! It's time we get some of that practice in. Now remember! The first team to get everything done gets first serve in the mess this evening!
We're serving dillegrout.
*DEAFENING CHEERING ROARS*
Wow... You were right, Minneapolis.
Through the stomach lies the heart, Captain. Now come along. I want you to show me what you've learned this trip, too.
With pleasure, Minneapolis.
